Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Self-Managing Wireless Networks Using M3

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to automate two core management functionalities for wireless networks - performance management and fault management. These functionalities are critical to providing high-quality and reliable wireless communications. To achieve this goal, this research develops a systematic framework, called M3, which measures, models, and manages wireless networks. M3 uses measurement data to drive model construction. In this way, the model can more closely reflect a given network than a generic network model. In the meantime, the simplicity of the network model permits efficient analysis and control.

To realize the framework, the research develops novel methodology for measuring and inferring wireless interference and traffic demands in a scalable and accurate fashion. Based on the measurement data, network embedding is used to construct simple and flexible models to facilitate network analysis and control. The research further develops robust optimization, stochastic programming, and outlier detection techniques for network optimization, troubleshooting, and recovery. To demonstrate the practical values of the approaches, this work will develop a complete toolkit for wireless network measurement, modeling, and management, and apply them to managing wireless networks at home, on campus, in enterprises, and at medical clinics. The techniques and toolkit developed can significantly improve current wireless network operations and facilitate new wireless network development. Finally, the research results of the project will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate curriculum.

The goal of the research is to automate two core management
functionalities for wireless networks -- performance management and
fault management. These functionalities are critical to providing
high-quality and reliable wireless communications. During the course
of this project, the PI has led her students to develop a series of
new wireless network models, optimization and diagnosis techniques,
and protocols to enhance wireless performance and resilience. In
particular, they have made the following contributions:

1) Developed accurate wireless network models: we accurately modeled
   wireless interference [MobiCom07, SIGCOMM08, SIGMETRICS11]. These models allow us to support predictable optimization of wireless network
   performance (i.e., what is optimized is what can be achieved in a
   real network).

2) Developed wireless network optimization and protocols:

   - Developed a series of novel routing protocols for wireless mesh
     networks and sensor networks, including S4 [NSDI07,ToN10], SOAR
     [TMC09], POWOR [SIGMETRICS11], and O3 [MobiHoc11]. Small State
     and Small Stretch (S4) routing protocol is the first routing
     protocol that achieves a worst-case routing stretch of 3 in large
     wireless networks while using small routing state. SOAR, POWOR,
     and O3 are opportunistic routing protocols that significantly
     improve wireless mesh network performance under lossy wireless
     links.

    - Developed model-driven optimization of Wi-Fi networks
      [SIGCOMM08, SIGMETRICS11]. These optimization algorithms can
      efficiently optimize wireless performance under non-convex
      wireless models.

    - Developed topology control algorithms through channel assignment      and  power control [ICNP07,TMC07].

    - Designed new transmission and retransmission techniques to maximize network throughput [CoNEXT07,IWQoS09].

    - Designed and implemented efficient vehicular content distribution system  [CoNEXT10].

 3) Enhanced other important network management capabilities:

   - Developed techniques to troubleshoot genuine network faults or
     user misbehaviors [SIGMETRICS05,CRC06,DSN07,TDSC10]. In
     particular, our work is the first work that focuses on receiver
     misbehaviors in Wi-Fi and develops counter-measure techniques.

   - Designed localization algorithms for both static and mobile
     networks [MC2R07,MobiCom10] that achieve significantly higher
     localization accuracy than the existing approaches.

   - Studied the impact of selfish behaviors in disruption tolerant
     networks (DTNs), and developed incentive-aware routing schemes
     for DTNs [ICNP08]. This is the first work that focuses on
     incentive issues in DTNs.

This research project has trained many students in conducting networking research.
